docs.lead_paragraph: Pfizer Inc. and Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida announced yesterday that they were extending a program for Pfizer to pay for health counseling for poor patients, saying that millions of dollars were saved and that patients' health had improved. The Pfizer program, which will now run through September 2005, is one of four being operated by drug companies in return for favored positions on Florida's Medicaid formulary, a list of drugs approved by the state for Medicaid recipients.

headline.main: Pfizer Extends Florida Program for Poor

docs.abstract: Pfizer Inc and Gov Jeb Bush are extending program for Pfizer to pay for health counseling for poor patients in Florida, saying that millions of dollars were saved and that patients' health has improved; program, which will run through September 2005, is one of four being operated by drug companies in return for favored positions on Florida's Medicaid formulary, list of drugs approved by state for Medicaid recipients; Pfizer says it will deliver $45 million in savings and program investments from July 2003 to September 2005; Bernard P Horn, policy director at Center for Policy Alternatives, liberal group that specializes in state issues, says Florida is losing remarkable amount of money through Pfizer program; says state would be better off if it hired independent companies to provide health counseling for Medicaid recipients and forced Pfizer and other drug companies to provide rebates for drugs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: At the Trey Whitfield School in a bleak corner of Brooklyn, toddlers imitate consonant and vowel sounds and learn that ''cup'' starts with C, not K. Teenagers understand that the rules prohibit gold teeth, coarse talk in the hallways and hip-hop fashions. All jump to their feet when an adult enters the classroom. ''Good morning, Mr. Whitfield,'' the children chant, welcoming A. B. Whitfield, who runs this 20-year-old private school where poor black and Hispanic youngsters consistently excel, compared with their public school counterparts.

headline.main: A Private School That Thrives on Rules; Minority Students Excel at Brooklyn Site. Is It a Model or an Anomaly?

docs.abstract: Article on 20-year-old Trey Whitfield School in bleak section of Brooklyn, where minority children learn academics and behavior in no-nonsense atmosphere fostered by A B Whitfield; photos; private school, which spends only $4,000 per student and relies on tuition, has few frills but students perform two or three years above grade level on national tests; Whitfield says structure, calm and safety are prerequisites for learning; supporters say results also show importance of leadership and parental involvement over money (M)
docs.snippet: At the Trey Whitfield School in a bleak corner of Brooklyn, toddlers imitate consonant and vowel sounds and learn that ''cup'' starts with C, not K. Teenagers understand that the rules prohibit gold teeth, coarse talk in the hallways and hip-hop...

docs.lead_paragraph: Gay marriage is the most contentious issue to emerge on the Canadian political scene since Quebec threatened to secede in 1995. Opinion polls show it cuts a fissure across class, age, regions, gender and religious lines -- a recipe for sharp discord in most societies, rich or poor. But this is Canada, a country that has never suffered a revolution or civil war, where compromise, consensus and civility are the most cherished political values.

headline.main: Gay Wedding Bells. Why No Hubbub? It's Canada.

docs.abstract: Canada's tradition of avoiding vigorous public disagreement and debate discussed in light of muted public discussion of deeply divisive issue of whether gay couples have right to marry; some social scientists believe Canada is merely going through serene pause; most historians say current calm is more the rule and loud debates of 1970's, 80's and 90's the exception; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Gay marriage is the most contentious issue to emerge on the Canadian political scene since Quebec threatened to secede in 1995. Opinion polls show it cuts a fissure across class, age, regions, gender and religious lines -- a recipe for sharp discord...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration has quietly told Congress that it should not provide Medicare drug benefits to six million poor elderly and disabled people because they are already eligible for similar help through state Medicaid programs. Administration officials said they were siding with the Senate, against the House and all 50 governors, on one of the most divisive issues in the Medicare legislation.

headline.main: Senate Wins Support on a Medicare Issue

docs.abstract: Bush administration quietly tells Congress that it should not provide Medicare drug benefits to six million poor elderly and disabled people because they are already eligible for similar help through state Medicaid program; comes down on side of Senate and against House, all 50 governors, AARP, Consumers Union and Catholic Health Assn, who argue that Senate plan would violate principle rooted in history of Medicare that all benefits are generally available to all beneficiaries, regardless of their income (M)
docs.snippet: The Bush administration has quietly told Congress that it should not provide Medicare drug benefits to six million poor elderly and disabled people because they are already eligible for similar help through state Medicaid programs.    Administration...

docs.lead_paragraph: Medco Health Solutions Inc., the prescription drug benefit provider, has been subpoenaed by the Florida attorney general's office as part of an investigation into its dealings with health maintenance organizations, a company spokesman said yesterday. Medco received a subpoena on Aug. 14, the spokesman, Jeffrey Simek, said, and it is discussing its response. Medco disclosed the information in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The subpoena seeks copies of contracts between Medco and some H.M.O.'s as part of a criminal investigation, Mr. Simek said. He declined to identify the H.M.O.'s.

headline.main: MEDCO SUBPOENAED BY FLORIDA'S ATTORNEY GENERAL

docs.abstract: Medco Health Solutions Inc, prescription drug benefit provider, is subpoenaed by Florida attorney general's office as part of probe into its dealings with health maintenance orgranizations (S)
docs.snippet: Medco Health Solutions Inc., the prescription drug benefit provider, has been subpoenaed by the Florida attorney general's office as part of an investigation into its dealings with health maintenance organizations, a company spokesman said yesterday....

docs.lead_paragraph: The room is filled with physicians from all over the country. It was silent until a few moments ago, when the first sad gasp was heard from the far corner. Now tearful faces fill the room. I've asked each doctor here to write a letter to a patient about something unresolved. The doctors will never mail these letters; instead, they have been instructed to write as openly and truthfully as they can.

headline.main: Beyond the Blame: A No-Fault Approach to Malpractice

docs.abstract: Dr Dan Shapiro, University of Arizona College of Medicine psychologist and author, holds that no-fault system of compensating patients for medical errors would be far superior to current and prevalent malpractice litigation; details how fear of malpractice often causes doctors to hide mistakes from patients; outlines possible process of reporting errors to commissions made up of patients and physicians and suggests ways system might deal with doctors, who continue to cover up their mistakes; recognizes that change to no-fault malpractice would not be easy to implement, but holds new system would be fair to both doctors and patients and provide better medical care; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Carol Moseley Braun formally announced today that she was seeking the presidency of the United States, contrasting herself, as a black woman, with the otherwise all-male pool of Democratic candidates. Speaking with the poise that has characterized her performance at the Democratic debates, Ms. Braun, who is the only black woman to have served in the Senate, promoted themes of ''partnerships for peace, prosperity and progress'' and an ''American renaissance'' in an announcement tour to colleges in Washington, South Carolina and her home state, Illinois.
docs.abstract: Carol Moseley Braun announces bid for presidential nomination, stressing she is only black woman in otherwise all-male pool of Democratic candidates, announcement tour to colleges in Washington, DC, South Carolina and Illinois; has struggled to raise money and build support for campaign; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two powerful insurance groups announced today that they would merge, forming a huge lobby that could speak with one voice on Medicare and industry regulation. The Health Insurance Association of America, which began as a lobby for traditional insurance companies, said it would join the American Association of Health Plans, which began as a spokesman for health maintenance organizations. Members of the two groups provide coverage for more than 200 million people.

headline.main: Health Insurers Gain A Huge New Lobby

docs.abstract: Health Insurance Association of America, lobby for traditional insurance companies, to merge with American Association of Health Plans, spokesman for health maintenance organizations, to form huge lobby to speak with one voice on Medicare and industry regulation; groups' members cover 200 million people; Karen M Ignagni will be president of organization (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A Pompano Beach urologist pleaded guilty to reduced charges for giving about 100 prostate cancer patients lower dosages of a medication than he billed their insurance companies for. The urologist, Dr. Victor Souaid, pleaded guilty to 59 counts of unlicensed wholesale distribution of a prescription drug and health care fraud. Prosecutors agreed to drop a charge of product tampering. Dr. Souaid is to be sentenced on Dec. 19 and faces up to four years and three months in prison. He will also lose his medical license. The drug, Lupron, is supposed to stop prostate cancer from worsening by halting production of the hormone testosterone.

headline.main: National Briefing | South: Florida: Doctor Pleads Guilty In Drug Fraud

docs.abstract: Dr Victor Souaid of Pompano Beach, Fla, pleads guilty to giving about 100 prostate cancer patients lower dosages of drug Lupron than he billed their insurance companies for; faces prison term and loss of license (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Struggling through a third consecutive year of fiscal distress, states have again squeezed Medicaid, the nation's largest health insurance program, by scaling back eligibility, cutting benefits, increasing co-payments and freezing or reducing payments to doctors and hospitals. Vernon K. Smith, former Medicaid director of Michigan, said today that soaring health costs and plunging state revenues had forced virtually every state to take action to slow the growth of Medicaid, the health program for 51 million Americans.

headline.main: Rising Costs Prompt States To Reduce Medicaid Further

docs.abstract: Kaiser Commission on Medicaid and the Uninsured study finds states, struggling with continued fiscal distress, again squeezed Medicaid in fiscal 2003, scaling back eligibility, cutting benefits, increasing co-payments and freezing or cutting payments to doctors and hospitals; state officials see pressure to slow Medicaid spending continuing; nearly all states report steps to rein in prescription drug costs (M)
